content: Contest with magician won by deception.
Sham blind man throws suspicion on real blind.

He admits his deception so that his companion, who is really
blind, is punished. *Chauvin V 159 No. 83.
Opposing witnesses‘s pockets filled with dung.

French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 23; Missouri French: Carrière;
India: Thompson-Balys.
child: Thief dressed half white, half black.

In the shroud of the supposed dead man is hidden another
robber. *Type 966*; India: Thompson-Balys.
Sham dead man brought in sack by confederate.

Is killed by his intended victim. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Thief disguises voice and is allowed access to goods
(children).

Type 123, BP I 37ff.; Africa
(Kaffir): Theal 118, (Zulu): Callaway 144, (Basuto): Jacottet 62ff.; American
Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 236ff. Nos. 40, 42, 43; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS
XVII 116 No. 91.
Thief becomes monk in order to rob monastery.
Robber disguised as bear is killed.

Man allows himself to be carried off by monkeys, who
mistake him for cow: steals their magic cups.
Magician transforms self into crocodile to steal.
Steal hangings in palace. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Theft by disguise as son of owner.
Thief in disguise as long lost son-in-law.
Thief pretends to be girl’s bridegroom and calls for her.
Theft by disguise as owner‘s grandmother.
Thieves disguised as fine gentlemen steal provost’s purse.

Are admitted to court
without question. Nouvelles Récréations No. 80.
Theft by disguising as palace official.
Theft by disguise as woman servant.
Theft by disguise as merchant (or peddler).
Thief in the clothes of robbed bride kills bridegroom.

content:
In one cask is oil; in the others the robbers are hidden.
The girl kills them. *Type 954; *Penzer I 133 n. 1; *Fb “kiste” II 134; Chauvin V 83 n.
3; *Basset 1001 Contes II 302; *Wesselski Archiv Orientální II 432; Missouri
French: Carrière; Africa (Ekoi): Talbot 391.
child: Thief hidden in cage that is carried into house.

Entry by master thief into closely guarded city in
wood-gatherer‘s basket.

content:
Trickster feigns being pursued by drunken husband to obtain
entrance.
Thief enters treasury through secret passage.
child: Underground passage gives entrance to closed chamber.

Italian: Basile Pentamerone I No. 2; Jewish: Neuman;
India: *Thompson-Balys.

Thief enters treasury through passage made by him as
architect of the building.

Thief bores hole in house wall, then introduces blackened
pot as a feeler.

Thieves enter palace through hole in wall and abduct new
bride.
Theft from giant by fishing through chimney.

content: Thief copies key by making wax impression.

Swiss: Jegerlehner Oberwallis 312 No. 68; India:
Thompson-Balys.
child: Thief enters by burning off locks.

Entrance into wine cellar by removing lock during absence
of mother.

content:
Trickster brings rabbit under his coat. When the king‘s watchdog gives chase
the trickster enters and robs. DeVries FFC LXXIII 208f.

Thief learns location of dupe’s food supply by strewing
ashes.

Fills the dupe‘s bag with ashes and
cuts a hole in the bag. Africa (Benga): Nassau 155, 204 Nos. 19, 32, (Ekoi):
Talbot 57, 62, (Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 51 No. 6, 83 No. 13; Jamaica:
*Beckwith MAFLS XVII 248 No. 24; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 12ff.
No. 2.
child:
Girl made to carry shell from which ashes fall: she is thus
followed.

content: Theft of gold hoard by spying on secret hiding place.

Thief pretends to return grass that has stuck to his
clothes to ground where it belongs.
Theft by use of coat of invisibility.
Thief feigns illness to be taken in victim’s house.

(Cf. †K341.2.2.1.)
Ransacks it while “recovering.” Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

child: Man gulled into giving up his clothes.

N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 332 n. 199 (occurs in most
versions).

content:
Missouri French:
Carrière; India: Thompson-Balys; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 350; Cook Islands: Beckwith
Myth 270; West Indies: Flowers 503.
child:
The man claims to sleep thus and beguiles the ogre into sleeping, so as to rob
him. Type 1140*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1140.
Owner put to sleep and goods stolen.

Magic or drugs. Dickson 63, 67 n. 13, 68 n. 15; Irish
myth: Cross; Welsh: MacCulloch Celtic 107; Finnish: Kalevala rune 42; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G. 3/1142).

Master thief puts watchers to sleep and cuts off their
hair.
Theft after putting owner to sleep by lousing her.
Master thief puts guards to sleep and steals meat.

Guards fatigued by trickster so that they sleep while goods
are stolen.

Worthless object (animal) substituted for valuable while
owner sleeps.

Mouse‘s tail in mouth of sleeping owner causes him to cough
up magic object.

India: Thompson-Balys;
Africa (Kordofan): Frobenius Atlantis IV 134ff. No. 13.
Trickster steals magic doll while owner is asleep.

The foolishly concealed money: A man hangs a bag of money
in the top of a high tree.

Servant sleeping
with him steals it. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1858*.

Thief lies down in the space between the king‘s and the
queen’s bed and steals jewelry from both.
Theft by giving narcotic to guardian of goods.
India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 225.

content:
India: *Thompson-Balys; Oceanic (New Zealand, Tahiti, Mangaia, Hawaii,
Melanesia, Micronesia, Indonesia): Dixon 46, 59, 65; Maori: Clark 160; Hawaii:
Beckwith Myth 230; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (T-G. 3/931).
child:
A blind
man’s arrow is aimed for him by his mother (or wife) who deceives him into
thinking that he has missed his aim. She eats the slain game herself. Cheremis:
Sebeok-Nyerges; Eskimo (Greenland): Rasmussen III 78, 202; N. A. Indian:
*Thompson Tales 354 n. 278.

Theft from three old women who have but a single eye among
them.

The hero seizes their eye. *BP IV
112 n. 5; *Frazer Apollodorus I 155 n. 4.

Buzzard steals coyote’s eyes, while he is throwing them up
in the air.

N. A. Indian (Klikitat):
Jacobs U Wash II 36.

Blind beggar overheard telling that his money is kept in a
stick.

content: Owner gives up goods through flattery.
child: The raven with cheese in his mouth.

The fox flatters him into singing, so that he drops the
cheese. *Type 57; *Basset RTP VI 244 n. 4; Crane Vitry 172 No. 91; Wienert FFC
LVI 52 (ET 121), 97 (ST 115); Halm Aesop 204; *Chauvin III 76 No. 49; Jacobs
Aesop 202 No. 8; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 17 No. 11. -- Spanish
Exempla: Keller; India: Thompson-Balys; Korean: Zong in-Sob 29 No. 12.

Goat induces the camel to talk and meanwhile eats all the
food.

content:
Type 1166**; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Graham; N.
A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 303 n. 109b; Africa (Ibo, Nigeria): Basden 278,
(Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 52 No. 6, (Wakweli): Bender 63; American
Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 98 No. 20, Nights 61 No. 12.
child: Owner frightened from goods by report of approaching enemy.

Owners frightened away from goods by report of deadly
epidemic.

Poor parson thus rids himself of
unwelcome guests; they leave food they have brought. *Wesselski Arlotto II 217
No. 81.

Thieves steal pig and make it impersonate person with
plague.

Owner and family flee. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

Trickster quarrels with owner of goods, feigns death, and
frightens owner away.
Owner frightened away from goods by a bluff.

Dupe, made to believe that trickster becomes a wolf when he
yawns three times, flees and leaves his clothes behind him.

Porcupine, made to believe that rabbit‘s ears are horns,
flees and leaves food behind.

Africa
(Nuba): McDiarmid Sudan Notes and Records X 229f.
Owner frightened from goods by apparitions of the dead.

When they are turned
loose in the churchyard the parson and the sexton think that they are the souls
of the dead. Meanwhile the thief steals from them. *Type 1740; *BP III 388;
Italian Novella: *Rotunda (†K2334).
Thief frightens priest as the latter crosses cemetery.

Meanwhile a confederate steals his chickens. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.
Owner frightened from goods by trickster’s ferocious animal.

Pretended dog is really a lion. Africa (Ila, Rhodesia):
Smith and Dale II 388 No. 14.

Thief frightens away guards of his father‘s corpse by
impersonating demons.

Town crier is frightened by the voice of a cleric robbing a
grave.
Delivery boy is frightened into giving up his chickens.

Trickster upturns his eyelids and puts on boar’s tusks.
Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Trickster lights torches and bluffs old woman into giving
him money.

Torches alleged to belong to
man coming to collect damages from her. India: Thompson-Balys.
Servants frightened by ferocious actions of robbers;
give up masters‘ food. Pierre Faifeu No. 13.
Owner frightened away by thief disguised as devil.

Owner frightened from goods by trickster’s summons of wild
buffalo herd.

Trickster steals the
goods. Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 211 No. 428, 215 No. 446; Missouri
French: Carrière; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys.
Frightened robber leaves his coat behind.

Chauvin II 83 No. 5;
Bødker Exempler 273 No. 6.
Object falls on robbers from tree.

They flee and leave money. India: *Thompson-Balys; Korean:
Zong in-Sob 144, 147 No. 64.
Door falls on robbers from tree.
Cow-hide falls on robbers from tree.
They flee and leave money. India: *Thompson-Balys.
Person falls from tree on robbers.
They flee and leave money. India: *Thompson-Balys.
Robbers frightened from goods by the dead.
Corpse thrown among robbers frightens them from treasure.
Robbers frightened from goods by sham-dead man.
Robbers frightened from goods by man’s outcry.

Trickster hits a slain ox and cries out, “Those others did
it!” The thieves flee and leave their treasure. Type 1525D; India:
Thompson-Balys.

Animals climb on one another‘s backs and cry out; frighten
robbers.
Robber frightened from his goods by playing of bagpipe.
Robbers frightened from goods by hidden man.
Thieves steal chest containing hidden paramour.

Are frightened away by his outcry. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.
Robbers frightened from goods by Thumbling.

They can hear him but cannot see him. India:
Thompson-Balys.

Other thieves come to steal the bees, take the heaviest hive to the
forest and make a fire under it. They flee when they hear a man screaming in
the beehive. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1887*.
Guardian beast overcome by hero’s mirrors.
Robbers frightened from goods by man in tar and feathers.

Robbers coming to steal from stable frightened away by bear
staying the night there with his keeper.

Tricksters threaten to cook a robber. All the robbers flee
in terror, leaving them their booty. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 967*.

Sons of thief frightened by threatening to bring the three
strongest men to punish them.

Thieves frightened by ghosts who tie fruits to their hair,
which they think are missiles thrown at them.

content:
House filled with smoke so that owner gives trickster
lodging.
child: Fire set to village so that robbers can steal goods.

Trickster fills house with smoke so that partner cannot see
to eat.

content:
Oversalting food of giant so that he must go outside for
water.

Meantime his goods are stolen.
*Type 328; *Fb “salt” III 148b; Icelandic: Boberg.
child: Thief sends owner for water in leaky basket.
N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 87.

content: Thief ties owner‘s hair while he escapes with goods.
Owner’s interest distracted while goods are stolen.

Type 15*; Lithuanian: Balys Index Nos 1525J, 2425, 2436*;
India: *Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda.
child:
Trickster reports lost money; searchers leave him in
possession of premises.

Unable to find a
place by the inn fire the trickster mentions that he has lost money on the
road. One by one the guests slip out to search and leave him the fire.
*Wesselski Arlotto I 203 No. 34; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Types 1, 1*; India:
Thompson-Balys; S. A. Indian (Apapocúva-Guarani); Métraux MAFLS XL 112.

Animal feigns death repeatedly and then entices owner from
goods.

Japanese: Ikeda; American Negro
(Georgia): Harris Remus 72 No. 15; (North Carolina): Parsons JAFL XXX 172,
(Virginia): Bacon and Parsons JAFL XXXV 275f.; Andros Islands, Bahamas: Parsons
MAFLS XIII 10 No. 8.

Man feigns sickness in order to go back to steal hidden
gold.

Thief distracts attention by apparently hanging (stabbing)
himself.
Thief persuades owner of goods to dive for treasure.

Meantime robs him. India: Thompson-Balys; Africa
(Mpongwe): Nassau 18ff. No. 2; West Indies: Flowers 504.
Owner persuaded to climb tree while goods are stolen.

Owner of horse climbs tree after thief, who drops down and
rides off on owner‘s horse.
Owner enticed to chase game while goods are stolen.

Spanish: Espinosa Jr. No. 8; India: *Thompson-Balys;
Japanese: Ikeda.

Theft of horses (cattle) by letting loose a rabbit so that
drivers join in the chase.

Partridge pretending to be wounded entices woman from food
while jackal eats it.
Shoes dropped to distract owner’s attention.

The thief drops two
shoes in different places and steals a ram while the shepherd goes after the
shoes. *Type 1525D; *BP III 390 n. 2; Missouri French: Carrière; India:
*Thompson-Balys; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 160 No. 22; Andros
Islands, Bahamas: Parsons MAFLS XIII 11 No. 9; Antigua, British West Indies:
Johnson JAFL XXXIV 74 No. 33; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 86 No.
28.

Animal‘s cry imitated to distract owner’s attention from
his goods.

Meantime rascal steals an
animal. Type 1525D; *BP III 391 n. 2.

Baby‘s cry imitated to distract owner’s attention from his
goods.

Cattle let loose so as to distract owner‘s attention from
his goods.

Cat made to mew so as to distract owner’s attention from
his goods.

Golden deer sent to entice girl‘s guardians away, so she
can be abducted.

Thief pretends to show how horse can be stolen; rides it
off.

Trickster pretends to ride home for tools to perform
tricks.

Rides away on horse. Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. 1532*; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. 1528*; Rumanian: Schullerus
FFC LXXVIII No. 1332*.

Thief pretends to horse dealer that he wishes to buy a
horse.

Dealer allows him to climb on horse
to see how he rides; thief runs off with horse. India: Thompson-Balys.

Thief shows knife-maker use of purse-cutting knife: cuts
his purse and robs him.

King loses signet ring while endeavoring to learn from a
thief the art of stealing.

Thief tells his pursuer that the thief has gone to heaven
by way of a tree.

While the man lies on
the ground and looks up, the thief steals his horse. *Type 1540; **Aarne FFC
XXII 3--109, especially 93ff.

Thief persuades owner to take his place so he can go and
catch thief: really steals owner’s horse.
Trickster bribes guards to start a fight.

While the master goes to investigate, the trickster enters
his bed with his wife. Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 129 No. 1525.
Owner’s attention distracted by man fishing in street.

Meanwhile the man‘s confederates rob the dupe. *Type
1525C.

Guard (owner) sent to see a cat which fishes for her
master.

Goods stolen in his absence.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Trickster falsely announces marriage celebration and
distracts owner’s attention.
Tailor throws piece of cloth out of the window.

The stingy woman has the tailor come to her house to cut
cloth. He throws a piece out of the window, “the devil‘s share”. While the
woman has gone after it he cuts off a piece for himself. Type 1567***.

Master thief pretends to throw needle and thread in anger
at his son.

But it contains stolen cloth.
India: Thompson-Balys.

Thief steals belongings of his wife’s paramour while the
latter is calling on her.
One thief distracts attention of owner while other steals.
Thief steals pastries while confederate makes a purchase.
Stone thrown to attract attention of shark guardians.

Man then slips in cave and steals lobsters. Hawaii:
Beckwith Myth 443.
Trickster entices children to dance and steals their food.
Thieves ask nurse maid to dance while they steal prince.

Helpful animal amuses princess with tricks and secures key
to treasury.

Africa (Nubia): Basset Contes
populaires d‘Afrique 133ff. No. 52, (Swahili): Steere 13ff.

Trickster poses as entertainer: steals meat while host
assembles friends.

One thief steals, the other relates the situation, in the form of a tale, to
the gentleman who is being robbed. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1525J*; Russian:
Andrejev 1525II*; India: *Thompson-Balys.

The thief orders the farmer to crawl into a tub and to sit there
quietly and not look about, while he makes a magic spell (cure him of
childlessness). Meanwhile, he steals all the farmer‘s property. Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. 1629*; Italian Novella: Rotunda (†K341.16); India:
Thompson-Balys.
Fire set in order to distract attention.

India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Duala): Lederbogen JAS IV
65.
Man stands on pillory to attract attention.

Confederate picks pockets of men who come to jeer.
England: Baughman.

Fox drops goldsmith’s child to get him away from gold bench
he is working on and thus steal gold.

Partridge plays hide-and-seek with girls while fox eats the
curds they are taking to market.
Trickster starts argument and steals from arguers.
Miser enticed from his money by report of “money tree”.

Man lures fox-husband of girl away by means of cock-decoy
and runs away with the girl.

content:
Three men are quarreling over the possession of a rescued
girl. The umpire will give her to the one who soonest returns with the arrow he
shoots. While they run, he takes the girl. Chauvin V 91 No. 196, 212 No. 121;
India: Thompson-Balys.
Thief advises owner to go away; meantime steals the goods.
Africa (Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 69 No. 10.
child:
Innkeeper deceived into going under the floor of the
granary; meantime robbed.
Owner sent on errand and goods stolen.

Louisiana Creole: Fortier MAFLS II 110; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Africa (Fjort): Dennett 77 No. 17; American Negro (Georgia):
Harris Friends 77 No. 1, Nights 241 No. 41; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 251
No. 29, 255 No. 36; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 97; West Indies:
Flowers 505.
Bread dropped in mud; messenger returns for more.

A youth poses as a rich man‘s servant and gets a sack of
bread from a baker. The baker boy is to go along and collect. The rascal drops
two loaves in the mud and sends the boy back for fresh ones. Meantime he runs
off with the rest of the bread. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 651.

Woman falsely told that her father is wounded leaves her
water pot with jackal. India: Thompson-Balys.
Thief advises that slaughtered meat be hung up over night.

Meantime he steals it. Africa (Zulu): Callaway 6; American
Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 123 No. 23.
The stingy parson and the slaughtered pig.

The stingy parson does not want to give any one a part of
his pig, which he has just slaughtered. The sexton advises him to hang the pig
up in the garden over night so as to make everyone think that it has been
stolen. The sexton steals it himself. *Type 1792; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 790;
Lee Decameron 257f.; Taylor MPh XV 226.
Thief advises that new cloth be hung in the open overnight.
Steals it while owner sleeps. Pierre Faifeu No. 21.

Companion sent away so that rascal may steal common food
supply.

India: Thompson-Balys; Africa
(Cameroon): Gantenbein 70; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 128 No. 24,
230 No. 39, 280 No. 47, Work JAFL XXXII 403, (Virginia): Smiley JAFL XXXII 368,
(South Carolina): Parsons JAFL XXXIV 8, MAFLS XVI 31f.; Cape Verde Islands:
Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 109 No. 38.

Monkeys lure tortoise into a tree and carry away his load
of salt.

Cheat induces dupe to go get food reported found and steals
clothes as soon as they are left behind.

content: Owner persuaded that his goods are spoiled.

(Cf. †K355.) Bødker
Exempler 292 No. 50; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 123 No. 23.
child:
Trickster gives a woman a knife to cut him a slice of white
bread.

He gets the whole loaf when he says
that he has just cut a dog with the same knife. Type 1578*.

Servant places his one fish with Brahmin‘s entire catch; receives all since
Brahmin considers all polluted. India: *Thompson-Balys.

Servant eats all of master’s anchovies. When master asks for some, the servant
brings in a covered dish, and tells him that the fish smell very bad. The
master tells the servant to throw them away. Spanish: Childers.
Trickster cuts up partridges with his knife.

He is given all of them when he tells his companions that
he is an executioner. Spanish: Childers.
May take it all. India: Thompson-Balys.

Dupe persuaded that the dung has spoiled the field. He
gives the field to the trickster. Indonesia: Coster-Wijsman 25 No. 2.

Son-in-law steals father-in-law‘s pants by making latter
believe he has dirtied them.
Sympathetic helper sent for remedy and robbed.

Africa (Benga): Nassau 86 No. 4, (Thonga): Junod 221,
(Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 386 No. 12.
Thief sent into well by trickster.

A weeping boy tells a
passing thief that he has lost a silver cup in a well. The thief takes off his
clothes and goes after the cup, intending to keep it. He finds nothing. When he
comes up, his clothes have been stolen. Hdwb. d. Märchens I 346a n. 126; BP III
392f.; Wienert FFC LVI 84 (ET 502), 106 (ST 183); India: *Thompson-Balys.
Dupe left to care for child while his goods are stolen.

Antelope sends leopard for fire, eats game while leopard is
gone.

Africa (Kiyansi): Van Whig
Biblioteca Africana IV 52.

Thief guards his pursuer‘s horse while the latter follows a
false trail.

Steals the horse. *Type 1540; **Aarne FFC XXII 3-109; *BP II 440;
Berber: Basset Contes Berbères (Paris, 1887) I 114; India: Thompson-Balys.

King persuaded to change clothes with thief disguised as
old woman.

Thief rides king’s horse away.
India: Thompson-Balys.
Herdsman slaughters animals entrusted to him.
Woman persuaded to go after her forgotten comb.
Goods stolen by guard. India: Thompson-Balys.
Thief trusted to guard shawls during prayers.
Cloak as surety that owner will return.
Thief runs away with it. India: Thompson-Balys.

Thief takes mistress‘s ornaments across river on pretense
of keeping them safe, and then deserts her.
Prostitute claims to be intended victim’s daughter.

content: Trickster causes owner and another to fight over goods.

Meantime he steals it. Wienert FFC LVI 48 (ET 71), 119 (ST
293); Halm Aesop No. 247; Panchatantra III 10 (tr. Ryder 343); West Indies:
Flowers 505.
Trickster permitted to try on clothes.
Goes away with them. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 727.
child: Trickster persuades tailor to leave his goods.

Makes him believe he
will get order to clothe fifty poor. Trickster makes away with goods. (Or tries
on boots and makes away with them.) Nouvelles Récréations No. 23; Pierre Faifeu
No. 21; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Thief borrows cloak so to carry food.
Trickster permitted to try on ornaments.
Goes off with them. Cook Islands: Beckwith Myth 445.

content:
Trickster advises wife to slaughter pig and have the
trickster eat it all. Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 252 No. 30.

Trickster claims to be working magic spell over food and
eats it. India: Thompson-Balys.

Trickster asks hospitality: expels owner and appropriates
house.
child:
Crow asks hospitality of sparrow and gradually takes
possession of nest and kills young.

(Often
told of camel and tent.) India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Trickster pollutes house so that he is left in possession.

He is in upper room and
throws filth on those below (Cf. †K344.) American Negro (Georgia): Harris
Nights 26 No. 6; Bahama: Parsons MAFLS XIII 84, Edwards MAFLS III 74; West
Indies: Flowers 504.
child: Trickster pretends to have spit in wine accidentally.
Is allowed to drink it. Korean: Zong in-Sob 104 No. 56.

content: Tricksters feign death of their father.
Collect rent and flee. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Pickpockets strike man on leg so that he takes his hand off
his purse.
Signal for theft given in foreign language.
Means of hoodwinking guardian or owner--miscellaneous.
child: Theft by means of magic invisibility.

Thief beguiles guardian of goods by assuming equivocal
name.
Thief of sweetmeats says his name is Fly.

Child shouts to father, “Fly is eating,” etc. “Never mind
the fly, guard against the cow.” India: Thompson-Balys.
Trickster dupes woman into putting him into basket.
He thus learns where food is kept. India: Thompson-Balys.

Crow makes friends with pigeon so as to be able to steal
food in household to which he belongs.
Objects stolen by means of magic impersonation.

Jackal ordered to take meat to lion‘s family takes it to
his own.
Man calling self “her husband” abducts child.
Tricksters eat up food given them for bear.
Man eats up food given him by tiger as bait for deer.

Monk entrusted with care of getting husband for girl, takes
dowry himself.

Uncle entrusted with niece’s patrimony slanders her so
marriage will be broken off and he will not have to part with her money.

Covetous husband desiring wife‘s jewels tells her he has
vowed to offer them to deity.

content: Theft by presenting false order to guardian.

*Wesselski Mönchslatein
126 No. 109; India: *Thompson-Balys; Africa (Ibo, Nigeria): Basden 274; West
Indies: Flowers 506-8.
child:
Unique weapon got by misrepresenting to guardian use to
which it is to be put.

The numskull has been told to keep the sausage “for the long winter”. When the
trickster hears this, he claims to be Long Winter and receives the sausage.
*Type 1541; *Fb “tosse” III 832a, “pølse” II 907b; BP I 521, 526;
Christensen DF L 46; *Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 194 n. 3; Icelandic: Sveinsson FFC
LXXXIII No. 1541.
Ring to put on corpse’s finger.

A thief holds a corpse up to a lord‘s window. The lord shoots
the corpse and leaves to bury it. The thief goes to the lady and gets a sheet
to bury the corpse in and a ring to put on his finger. *Type 1525A; BP III 379;
Missouri French: Carrière; Jewish: Neuman.

A thief poses as a messenger from a husband
to his wife asking that a certain silver cup be sent for repairs. *Wesselski
Mönchslatein 126 No. 109; Scala Celi 101a No. 543; Mensa Philosophica No. 56;
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Stealing the platter for the intended gift.

Thief asks for silver platter saying that it is needed for
an intended gift of confections. Servant carrying platter is told to wait until
it is filled. Thief disappears with it. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Theft by posing as master of the house and learning where
goods are hidden.

Wife deceived in the dark. *Gering Islenzk Æventyri (Halle, 1883)
II 210ff.; India: *Thompson-Balys.
Hare in lion’s skin gets meat from lioness.

Fox drinks the milk of a tiger’s mate by giving her a
misleading message.
S. A. Indian (Chiriguano): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 180.
Deposit money secured by false order to banker‘s wife.

When banker refuses to redeliver deposit the owner
presents false tokens to wife. Jewish: Bin Gorion Born Judas II 245.
Theft by forgery: signature forged to obtain money.

Clerk mistranslates order given by master to maid, so that
pie goes to clerks.

Thief steals lawyer’s scarlet robe. Later he returns and tells lawyer‘s wife
that her husband had sent him for the hood for the robe. He obtains the hood
and escapes. Spanish: Childers.

(Cf. †K437.5, †K1354.1.) Thief sent to man’s house for water, demands money. Man‘s wife refuses and
thief shouts to the husband who replies, “Give him what he wants.” India:
*Thompson-Balys.

Hero reports to king that his ancestors (in heaven) want
him rewarded with gold.

content:
Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges; Africa (Luba): DeClerq Zs. f.
Kolonialsprachen IV 221; Philippine (Tinguian) Cole 195.

Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 130 No. 1525G*; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Benga):
Nassau 160 No. 20; West Indies: Flowers 508.
child: Confederate allows self to be sold as slave.

Rent a room at an inn and empty the mattresses of feathers, take fire wood,
etc. Throw goods out of the window where confederate picks it up. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Wife tells him secret of buried money. Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II
1014.

Thief feeds stolen money in flour to animal, then asks for
ass.

The trickster has a cow that leads the parson’s cows to
him. He thus tests the parson‘s text, “He who gives in God’s name shall have it
back a hundred-fold.” *Type 1735; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 324; *Krappe Bulletin
Hispanique XXXIX 25; *Wesselski Mönchslatein 167 No. 129.

Brothers are given the choice of a cow or a calf. One chooses the cow
and thinks that he has the best of the bargain. The cow longs for the calf and
returns to it. Indo-Chinese: Scott Indo-Chinese 296.

A
cow allows itself to be sold; then returns to its master. Hindu: Keith 90.
Animal shams death and is sold.
Later made to disgorge rice. India: Thompson-Balys.

Speaking goat swallows gold coins in temple and voids for
master.

content: Trickster hides in food and eats it.

India: Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 57,
Coster-Wijsman 35 No. 16; Africa (Thonga): Junod 209.
child: Trickster throws fish off the wagon.

The fox plays dead; a
man throws him on the wagon of fish. The fox throws the fish off and carries
them away. *Type 1; BP II 116; Dh IV 225, 304; Krohn Bär (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO
VI) 46ff. -- Lappish: Qvigstad Lappiske Eventyr II 3, III 3; Louisiana Creole:
Fortier MAFLS II 115; Japanese: Ikeda; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 438;
Africa (Hottentot): Bleek 16 No. 8; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 17
No. 4, 306 No. 52, (South Carolina): Parsons MAFLS XVI 39, Stewart JAFL XXXII
395, (Virginia): Parsons JAFL XXXV 276;
Bahama: Parsons MAFLS XIII 10.

content:
By
pretending that he has been invited to be godfather, the trickster makes an
opportunity to steal the provisions stored by him and the dupe for the winter.
When he returns on successive occasions he reports the name of the child as
“Just Begun,” “Half Done,” etc. *Type 15; BP I 9; Dh IV 241; *Krohn Bar (Wolf)
und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 74ff.; *Fb “ræv” III 113b, “bjørn” IV 43b; *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 238.--Lappish: Qvigstad Lappiske
Eventyr III No. 3; French: Sébillot France III 63f.; Missouri French: Carrière;
Louisiana Creole: Fortier MAFLS II 19; New Mexican Spanish: Rael Hispania XX
231--4; Japanese: Ikeda; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 437; Africa: Frobenius
Atlantis III 13, (Fjort): Dennett 90 No. 23; American Negro (Georgia): Harris
Remus 80 No. 17, Jones Negro Myths from the Georgia Coast (Cambridge, Mass.,
1888) No. 24, (Virginia): Parsons JAFL XXXV 253--55, (North Carolina): Parsons JAFL XXX 192f., (South Carolina):
Parsons MAFLS XVI 7--12, JAFL XXXII 394, XXXIV 3; Bahama: Parsons MAFLS XIII 1;
Bermuda: Parsons JAFL XXXVIII 240.
child:
Trickster eats food left by tiger (his trapping partner) at
snare.

Tiger accused of the theft. India:
Thompson-Balys.

content:
A rascal steals a priest’s watch. He tells the priest that
he has stolen a watch and offers it to him as a payment for a past favor. The
priest refuses to accept stolen goods. Commands the thief to return the watch
to the owner. “But the owner has refused to accept it.” “Then you may keep it.”
Danish: Kristensen Kirketjeneste 126.
Trickster pretends to teach dance: flees with valuables.

Thieves steal chickens and have mock funeral to cover
theft.

Trickster kisses pile of money, taking some in his mouth with every kiss.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Fire stolen by swallowing it and then escaping.
Blame for theft fastened on dupe.

*Penzer IV 191f. n. 1; Boccaccio Decameron VIII No. 6 (Lee
257); Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries‘s
list No. 129.
child:
Thief accuses his companion of having stolen the gold they
have both stolen.
Dupe’s food eaten and then blame fastened on him.
Trail of stolen goods made to lead to dupe.

The crane in revenge for
the loss of her young ones strews pieces of fish from the dwelling of the
mongoose to that of the snake. The mongoose follows the trail and kills the
snake. *Penzer V 61 n. 3; Bødker Exempler 287 No. 37; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Stolen goods taken to dupe’s house so that he is accused.

Icelandic: Boberg;
Bødker Exempler 303 No. 74; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Greek: Frazer Apollodorus
II 178 n. 1 (Palamedes); Indonesia: DeVries‘s
list No. 100.

Crow causes serpent to try to swallow a stolen collar and
thus be accused of the theft.

Chauvin II
87 No. 23; Penzer V 47 n. 3, 214, 226f.

Necklace dropped by crow into snake’s hole leads men to
kill snake which had eaten the crow‘s fledglings.

Bødker Exempler 281 No.
25; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Surreptitious transfer of stolen object to innocent
person’s possession brings condemnation.
India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 349, 892.
Stolen goods left in suitor‘s room.

Impoverished lover falsely accused so as to be rid of him.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Thief makes believe that he has been robbed of money
entrusted to him.

Thief successfully accuses owner of having stolen property
he covets.

content:
Accused of eating the lamb’s heart, the thief maintains that it had no
heart. *Type 785; *BP II 149, 153; Wienert FFC LVI 40, 107; Oesterley No. 83;
Herbert III 205; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 57; Penzer V 130 n. 1; India:
*Thompson-Balys.
child:
Accused of eating the goose‘s leg, the thief maintains that it had no leg, and
cleverly enforces his point by showing geese standing on one leg. (Usually the
master confounds the rascal by frightening the geese so that they use both
legs) *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 229 No. 75; Boccaccio Decameron VI No. 4
(*Lee 177); Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2424*; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. No. 191;
Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys; West Indies: Flowers 508.
Thief maintains that the bird had no tail. Africa (Kaffir): Theal 184.

The ass as toll-gatherer is killed by the lion for asking for toll. The fox
eats the ass’s heart. When the lion asks for it, the fox replies that the ass
could have had no heart since he was such a fool as to ask the lion for toll.
**Keidel “Die Eselherz Fabel” Zs. f. vgl. Litgsch. n. ser. VII No. 58; Gaster Exempla 229 No.
244; Penzer V 130 n. 1; *Chauvin II 99 No. 58; Bødker Exempler 299 No. 63;
Spanish Exempla: Keller; Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys.

content: Thief claims to have been transformed into an ass.

While the owner sleeps the thief steals his horse, hitches
himself to the wagon, and claims that he is the horse transformed into a man.
*Type 1529; *BP III 9, 391 n. 3; Chauvin VII 137; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin
II 229 No. 487; *Basset 1001 Contes I 492; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 150 No. 1852*;
Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 437.

Thief escapes by leaving animal’s severed tail and claiming
that the animal has escaped and left his tail.
child:
Thief
steals animals and sticks severed tails into the ground, claiming that animals
have escaped underground. *Type 1004; BP III 392 n. 1; *Fb “hale” I 537, “svin” III 676a; Icelandic:
Sveinsson FFC LXXXIII No. 1004; Missouri French: Carrière; Louisiana Creole:
Fortier MAFLS II 110 No. 2; Indonesia: DeVries‘s
list No. 241; Africa (Vai): Ellis 249 No. 41; American Negro (Georgia): Harris
Remus 98 No. 20, Nights 230 No. 39, 241 No. 41, (Virginia): Smiley JAFL XXXII
368, (South Carolina): Parsons MAFLS XVI 31f., JAFL XXXIV 8; Bahama: Cleare
JAFL XXX 228; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 252 No. 29; Cape Verde Islands:
Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 109 n. 2, 113.

The thief kills one ox and puts the tail in another ox’s
mouth: the owner thinks one ox has eaten the other. Type 1004; *BP III 392 n.
2; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1525G*; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. 1525G*;
Russian: Andrejev No. 1525G*.
Stolen sheep‘s tails severed and put in tree.

Owner made to believe that they have escaped through the
air. *Type 1004.

content: Thief successfully claims that stolen goods are his own.
child:
Grain-thief’s wagon falls into ditch: duped owner helps
him.

The thief makes the owner believe
that the grain belongs to the thief. Type 1564*.
The stolen pot pawned with the real owner.

The thief gets a receipt from the owner and thus defends
himself when accused of theft. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 823; cf. No. 860.

Thief successfully claims that stolen image has been given
him by the saint himself.

content:
Stolen animal disguised as person so that thief may escape
detection.
child: Stolen sheep dressed as person sitting at helm of boat.

Stolen sheep dressed as baby in cradle, so that thief may
escape detection.

(Mak.) Whiting Speculum
VII 552; Fb “lam” II 370a, “hundehvalp” IV 228b; *Baugh MPh XV 729; *Smyser
JAFL XLVII 378; *Stroup JAFL XLVII 380, Southern Folklore Q. III 5f.; *Cosbey
Speculum X 310ff.; Middle English: Second Shepherd’s Play; Irish myth: Cross
(†K521.1.3); Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 144 No. 1735B*.

Stolen animal magically transformed so that thief may
escape detection.

Thief has his companion cut off his head so that he may
escape detection.

*Type 950; BP III
395ff.; *Krappe “Trophonios and Agamedes” Archiv für Religionswissenschaft XXX 228-241; Italian Novella:
*Rotunda; Greek: Grote I 122; India: *Thompson-Balys.

Companion‘s arm allowed to be cut off so as to prevent
detection.

Thief has had his arm cut off
as he enters a hole in a wall. He lets his companion also enter and have his
severed. *DeVries Tijdschrift voor Nederlandsche Taal- en Letterkunde XLV
213ff.

Thief’s confederate cuts off own arm to furnish alibi for
family‘s grief.

(Previously he had severed
father’s or brother‘s head to escape detection.) Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Elephant cuts piece from own leg and puts it on shelf, lest
he be accused of stealing meat.

content:
In one night a thief
pawns a cow four times, always stealing it immediately and finally delivering
it back to its owner. *Wesselski Mönchslatein 119 No. 100.

Plays all night for dance while confederate commits actual theft. Jamaica:
Beckwith MAFLS XVII 244 No. 21.
child:
Africa (Yoruba): Ellis 271 No. 6, (Nago): Basset Contes
populaires d’Afrique 217ff. No. 90.

content:
Detection of theft of bull escaped by putting boots on
bull.
Thieves stretch chain across road and evade pursuers.
Quartered thief‘s body sewed together to escape detection.
Marked culprit marks everyone else and escapes detection.
child:
Many persons admit theft so that it is impossible to find
real thief.

content: Repentant thief pretends to have found stolen cow.

Upbraids owner for not
guarding her better. *Wesselski Mönchslatein 119 No. C; Mensa Philosophica No.
52.
child: Thief pretends to have recovered stolen horse.

Returns it to owner
after using it all he desires. Nouvelles Récréations No. 24.

content: Thief swallows stolen goods to escape detection.
child: Flower thief eats flowers to escape detection.

content:
The owner is duped by thief who gives him the task of
solving a riddle about the theft just accomplished.

Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1635*; Russian: Andrejev No.
1545*.

child: Thief cannot remember whom he delivered the goods to.

Though he has eaten the food trusted to him, he claims to
have delivered it, but cannot remember the person who opened the door. *Pauli
(ed. Bolte) No. 63.
Thief avoids detection by disguising as a woman.
Umpire awards his own stolen coat to thief.

Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1525K*; Russian: Andrejev No.
1525 I*.
Stolen bacon offered to the owner.

Making off with bacon, thief accidentally enters farmer’s
living-room. Boldly says: “Master, the devil from hell sends you bacon.” The
farmer: “Take yourself off to hell with the bacon.” Lithuanian: Balys Index No.
1627B*.

Thief paints horse black on one side and leaves other side
white.

Hoodwinked guardians make
conflicting report of theft. Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges.
Husks replaced in granary so theft of grain is unnoticed.
Goldsmith as thief in king‘s treasury.

Makes golden human figure and says it is a corpse. Gets by
guards. India: Thompson-Balys.

Thieves escape detection by carrying woman on bier and
drowning her outcries with wailing.
Blame for theft fastened on inanimate objects.
Blame for theft fastened on fairies.

content:
Robber mistakenly carries off worthless goods and leaves
valuable.
child: Thief hoping to gain bigger booty, loses smaller.

Thieves directed to a hornet’s nest as supposed money
hiding place.

Two cheats exchange articles as genuine and both find
themselves cheated.

content: Stolen object magically returns to owner.

Irish myth: *Cross. See
all references to †D1602 and its subdivisions.

Thief condemned when witnesses of theft are able to find
the stolen goods.
King‘s daughter put into brothel to catch thief.

Apparently dead woman revives when thief tries to steal
from her grave.

Type 990; **Bolte Zs. f.
Vksk. XX 353; XXX--XXXII 127; *Hertel ibid. XXI 282.

Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 48; West Indies: Flowers
509.
child:
Horse catches arm of thief and holds on until help comes.
Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content: Magic statue betrays a thief by indirection.

He has threatened to smash the head of the magic statue if
it betrays him. The statue says, “Whoever would tell the truth now is likely to
have his head smashed.” *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 8.

Mouse’s tail in mouth of sleeping thief causes him to cough
up swallowed magic ring.
Person being robbed deceives robbers and calls help.
child:
Clever woman being robbed makes excuse for screaming and
summoning help.

Clever husband being robbed induces wife to make outcry and
summon help.

Owner pretends to help burglars to divide booty: handles
weights so loudly that police are summoned.

content:
Thief steals pig. Slaughters it together with one of his
own and takes both to market. Puts little pig inside large one to avoid paying
tax on two. Boy notices three hind legs. Thief is caught. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.
Clever girl discovers robber and cheats him.
child:
The girl seizes the robber concealed under the bed by the
beard and says: “What a coarse bundle of flax.
I need a finer one.” Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 959A*.

Disguised robber in night-lodging tries to pull up
confederate on rope: princess discovers him and catches him.
Girl tells the thief money is in chest.

When he looks in chest, girl drops lid on him. Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. 959C*.

content:
U.S.: Baughman; West Indies: Flowers 509f.; Jamaica:
*Beckwith MAFLS XVII 235 No. 4, 239 No. 10.
child: Husband makes rhymes about cakes wife has stolen.

content:
Blind thief trying to steal dates from withered tree killed
by slipping of rope.

child:
Spending the night in
company with a suspicious-looking stranger, the man does not go to sleep, but
leaves his clothes in bed and waits to see what will happen. When the stranger
wakes up in the night, he stabs at his sleeping companion, who shoots him down.
(Cf. †K525.1.) Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 965*.
Robber with hand of glory killed.

A robber disguised as a beggar gets night‘s lodging at a farm
house. Using a candle made of human fat or hand of a corpse, he tries to charm
the household into a deep sleep (†D1162.2.1). One man who is suspicious and has
not gone to sleep sees this and kills the robber. Lithuanian: Balys Index No.
963*.

Man scares robber with sausage; later boasts of event at inn. Robber hears
this. Innkeeper secretly lends man a real revolver; robber is shot down when
boldly attempting a second attack. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 970*.
Conqueror of robber discovers his money-stick.

Thinking that he has killed the robber, the man takes his
stick or knife with big handle. The robber recovers and, disguised as a beggar,
inquisitively looks at the stick. The man is suspicious and by examining finds
much money inside it. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 962*; Russian: Andrejev No.
961 I*.

Youth told by two robbers to go to town and sell bracelet for each. He goes and
offers to sell two slaves. Goes back with buyer and cries out “Did you say
both?” “Yes.” Youth is paid; robbers are enslaved. India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Thief loses his goods or is detected--miscellaneous.
child: Betrayal through exchange of stolen goods.

Thief claims that stolen goods are his own: detected by
master.

He has placed a coat on
the goods to be stolen. His associate changes the place of the coat. Chauvin II
83 No. 7; Bødker Exempler 273 No. 5; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Thief leaves food untouched when owner pretends to be
poisoned by it.

(Playing poison.) American
Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 54 No. 7, Nights 297 No. 50; Bahama: *Parsons
MAFLS XIII 122; West Indies: Flowers 511.

Sheep thief pretends to buy wethers from the ram, names the
price himself.

Owner overhears, takes the
ram to the thief to collect. U.S.: Baughman.

Robber induced to give respite and come to man‘s office to
get promised larger sum.

Tortoise asks greedy man to give him first ruby it has
given him to be sure second one will be perfect match: disappears into water
with it.
Owner pretends to think thief is family god and binds him.

Owner feigns madness and thus raises alarm: thieves
captured.

Hidden person sees robbers concealing treasure and takes
it.

Thief hides in large bottle to get into room: bottle put
into water to boil.

content:
Cuckolded man shuts wife‘s paramour in chest and lies on
the chest with latter’s wife.

Boccaccio
Decameron VIII No. 8 (Lee 261); Italian Novella: Rotunda.
child:
Cuckold unwittingly lies with wife on chest containing her
hidden paramour.

content:
Dupe induced to sit on sharp stones (concealed as soft
seat).

India: Thompson-Balys;
Cook Islands: Beckwith Myth 267; Tonga: Gifford 79, 83; Eskimo (Greenland):
Rink 438, (West Hudson Bay): Boas BAM XV 538; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 321
n. 159; Africa (Benga): Nassau 206 No. 32. See also all references to †F912.
child: Ungrateful river passenger kills carrier from within.

Crawls inside during the passage. (Porcupine and buffalo.)
India: Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 302 n. 104.

Jackal, swallowed by elephant so it can drink water in his
belly, eats elephant‘s liver and kills him.

Ungrateful rat defecates upon head of (or kills) octopus
that rescues him from sea.

Man transforms self to gadfly to enter giant’s stomach and
kill him.

S. A. Indian (Tehuelche):
Alexander Lat. Am. 336.

Man kills giant bear by crawling inside and cutting his way
out.
Animal tricked into seizing hollow log.

Man reaches through and pulls animal’s heart out. Irish
myth: *Cross.

content: Foxes crawl into whale’s house and are killed.

Koryak: Jochelson JE VI 319; Eskimo (West Hudson Bay):
Boas BAM XV 216; N. A. Indian: Boas RBAE XXXI 324.

child:
Adulteress pretends shame before male statue (mirror, male
fish).

Adulteress pretends to faint when her husband strikes her
with a rose.

She has allowed her lover to
abuse her. Fischer-Bolte 217.
Adulteress feigns great disdain of men;

will look at none but husband (and lover). Heptameron No.
43.
Women adorn their heads, though they are immoral below.
Wears gloves, etc. to bed. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Girl who is frightened by love becomes insatiable.
Oversensitive bride pleads a headache (or other excuse).

Groom retaliates with similar plea when she changes her
mind. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Doctor prescribes sexual intimacy for widow’s ills.

She claims to prefer death. Change of heart on daughters‘
plea. Daughters adopt treatment as a preventive. Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No.
21; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Wanted: a husband to manage estate.

Widow who claims to abhor intimacy rejects a eunuch with
business qualifications. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Man consoles daughter whose husband is dying by telling her he has picked
another husband for her. She feels insulted. No sooner does her husband die
than she asks her father for details. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

content:
Trickster claims to have found a bag of gold. Confederate
claims and receives it upon correct identification. Spectator is thus deceived
into trusting the trickster with a large sum of money. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
child:
Boy pretends to take long trip in order to pay debt of a
penny.

Thus he gets man’s confidence and
robs him. Korean: Zong in-Sob 124 No. 60.

content: Fox confesses sins but is immediately ready to steal again.
child: The wolf in the company of saints.

Promises to give up slaying animals. After wringing the
gander‘s neck, excuses self saying: ”He should not have hissed at the saint.“
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 165*.

content:
Hypocritical stepmother weeps as she tells departing
husband she will take good care of stepchildren though they beat her (she beats
them instead).
Hypocrite refuses gifts orally but stretches out his hands.

child: False ascetic in partnership with tiger shares his prey.

content:
Treacherous plan of hypocritical animal detected and
prevented.
child: Wolf offers to act as shepherd: plan detected.

Wienert FFC LVI 45 (ET 36), 68 (ET 326), 97 (ST 110); Halm
Aesop No. 283.

Wolf proposes abolition of dog guards for sheep: plan
detected.

Wienert FFC LVI 53 (ET 138), 96
(ST 99); Halm Aesop No. 269; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Fox feigns to be playing with sheep: dog drives him off.

Wienert FFC LVI 53 (ET 125), 96 (ST 96); Halm Aesop No.
38.

Dog caresses sick sheep: shepherd knows that he hopes for
sheep’s death.

Wienert FFC LVI 72 (ET
373), 96 (ST 104); Halm Aesop No. 372.

Wolf tries to entice goat down from high place: plan
detected.

Wienert FFC LVI *53 (ET 137), 96
(ST 90); Halm Aesop No. 270; Spanish: Espinosa III No. 216.
Famished wolf asks sheep to bring him water: plan detected.

Wienert FFC LVI 53 (ET 136), 96 (ST 91); Halm Aesop No.
284; Spanish: Espinosa III No. 216.
Wolf offers to act as midwife for sow: plan detected.

*Crane Vitry 202 No. 166; Herbert III 15; Wienert FFC LVI
46 (ET 41), 53 (ET 135), 96 (ST 86).

Cat offers to act as doctor for cock and hen: plan
detected.

Wienert FFC LVI 45 (ET 30), 53
(ET 127), 96 (ST 87); Halm Aesop No. 16.

Crocodile tells dog to drink in river without fear: plan
detected.
Cat hangs on wall pretending to be dead: mice detect plan.

Wienert FFC LVI 53 (ET 128), 96 (ST 97); Halm Aesop No.
15.

Fox‘s plan detected by crickets: cricket wings in his
excrement.

Wienert FFC LVI 53 (ET 126), 96
(ST 94, 222); Halm Aesop No. 400.
Jackal as nurse for leopard cubs eats their food.

content:
Thief tries to feed watchdog and stop his mouth: dog
detects plan.

Wienert FFC LVI 69 (ET 330),
96 (ST 103); Halm Aesop No. 164; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *1450A; Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Italian Novella: Rotunda; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II
533.

child:
”Would that Death take me in his stead.“ When Death comes she points to her
husband. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Peasant has kind words for daws, but drives them from his
seeds.

Wienert FFC LVI 68 (ET 323), 102
(ST 151); Halm Aesop No. 99.

content: Illness feigned in order to learn secret.
child: Illness feigned in order to get better food.

content: False guardian betrays refuge of fleeing lovers.
Love falsely pledged for wooer‘s benefit.

child:
Man announces finding lost jewel, but so softly that no one
hears.

He thus has clear conscience. India:
Thompson-Balys.

Hypocrite will not share in stolen chicken--only takes some
gravy.
Hypocrite breaks vow to give coin in charity.
Finds coin is short weight. India: Thompson-Balys.

Thief robs blind miser of his hoard and gives a tenth away
in charity in form of a banquet to the poor.

content: Miser goes to mass before committing usury.

King sends regrets for death of man he has ordered
executed.

child:
Man pretends friendship but attacks king to avenge
violation of his wife.

**A. H. Krappe The
Legend of Roderick, the last of the Visigothic Kings and the Ermanarich Cycle
(Heidelberg, 1923); Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Wolves sign false truce with sheep.

After the dogs have been dismissed the wolves devour the
sheep. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Wienert FFC LVI 75 (ET 411), 123 (ST 323); Halm Aesop No.
310.
Illusory shapes of animals made to appear on hilltops.

Tuatha Dé
Danann cause island to appear to be

Spanish:
Espinosa Jr. No. 172; Greek: Pauly-Wissowa s.v. ”Echo“; Chinese: Graham.

Wood-spirits imitate
falling of trees, etc. Slavic, Hindu: Máchal 265.

Fairies cause sound to appear to come from various
directions.

Man told that he can be cured only with blood of his own
child. He is made to believe that the child is killed. When he learns that the
child is still alive, the excess of joy cures him. *Chauvin VIII 133 No. 126.

(The
Old Man of the Mountain.) Potion is given to dupes who are led into what they
believe is Paradise. They are then forced to rob and kill to regain admittance
through death. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Injurious food (drink) has delusive sweet taste.
Palace appears to be floating on water--actually glass.
Trickster hides in bag in order to be carried.

His father imitates and is beaten. Indonesia:
Coster-Wijsman 34 No. 15, DeVries‘s list No. 294.
Trickster hides in box in order to be carried.

Africa (Western Sudan): Frobenius Atlantis VIII 145ff. No.
81.
Trickster hides in basket and is carried.
Girl hides lover under clothing upon which she sits.

content:
False proof: cloak dipped into water used as evidence of
stormy weather.

A drunken man is employed, by the woman who has accidently
slain three hunchback brothers, to throw one into the river. He does so. Then
she puts another out and finally the third. The man thinks they keep coming to
life. Finally he sees the woman‘s hunchback husband and drowns him. *Type
1536B; *BP III 485; **Pillet Das Fablaiu von les trois bossus menestrals
(1901); *Taylor MPh XV 223 n. 3; *Chauvin VIII 72; *Herbert III 203; Spanish:
Espinosa II Nos. 31f.; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys;
Japanese: Ikeda.

child:
Alleged to be a swift
deliverer of letters. *Type 1539; *BP II 10; Köhler-Bolte I 323; *Herbert III
35; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Alleged speaking hare sold as messenger.

content:
Types 1535, 1539; *BP II
10; Köhler-Bolte I 323; Missouri French: Carrière.

child: Horse which will not go over trees.

Salesman tells buyer that he is selling the horse because
it eats too much and will not climb trees. On the way home the horse bites
everyone and refuses to cross a bridge. Seller is literally correct. *Wesselski
Bebel I 133 No. 33; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 112; England: Baughman; Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. *1631.
The horse swifter than the rain.

Caught in the rain, a trickster finds that his horse will
not budge. He undresses, puts his clothes under the horse’s belly and keeps
them dry. When he reaches the king, he reports that his horse has run so fast
that he has had no time to get wet. The king buys the horse. *Wesselski Hodscha
Nasreddin I 228 No. 72.

Trickster grooms master‘s old mule and then sells him back
without detection at huge profit.

Trickster in disguise regains possession of his own horse
by trading with man whom he has duped once before.

He gives a description that is literally correct. U.S.:
*Baughman.
Selling or trading a balky horse.

Trickster temporarily lames valuable horse and buys him for
trifle.

Said to swallow up the cold so that if he is near, one may
sleep comfortably in the cold. India: *Thompson-Balys.
Dog alleged to chase hare and bring it to hunter’s home.
Sale of dog supposed to excrete sweet dung: dupe deceived.

content: Sale of dead buffalo by making him seem alive.

child:
Two jars full of live black wasps sold as interpreters of
foreign language.

Parrot knowing only two words sold as speaking foreign
language.
Animals made by magic exchanged for real ones.
The magic animals disappear. Welsh: MacCulloch Celtic 96.
Deceptive exchange: useless for magic object.

content: Sale of a sausage filled with blood.
Sale of worthless glass as diamond.

child: Pot of cow dung covered with cheese sold as cheese.

content: Exchange of alleged ghee (liquid butter) for goat (cow).
child: Pus from sore sold as ghee.

Earthen pot with rice water on top of which clarified
butter had been poured sold as a pot of clarified butter.
Green plantains sold as matured plants.

content: Cheaters sell each other valueless articles.

child:
Trick exchange: basket of stones for one of bread; a few
pieces of money shown through slit in basket-cover to dupe.

*Type 1539; BP II 10ff.; Penzer V 5--13; Italian Novella:
Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: Coster-Wijsman 26 No. 5.

*Type 1539; BP II 10; *Fb “hat” IV 202b; India:
Thompson-Balys; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 196, 443.
Pseudo-magic formula for making gold sold to king.

Gold required for its manufacture carried off by
manufacturer. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

It already has the ingredients in it. Jamaica: Beckwith
MAFLS XVII 242 No. 16.

content:
Dupe kills his wife (mother) and is unable to resuscitate
her. *Type 1535, 1539; BP II 10; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries‘s
list No. 275.
child:
Seven devils’ wives imitate ritual of death and
resuscitation done over hero;

not having
the real water of life and death, the seven enemy devils are killed. India:
Thompson-Balys.

The dupe takes it. “It is dog‘s dung,” he says and spits
it out. The trickster says that he is telling the truth and demands pay.
*Wesselski Gonnella 99ff. Nos. 4, 4a, 105 No. 9; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Sale of alleged oracular bamboo cup.

Woman sold a letter to wear around her neck which will
prevent eye trouble. It helps only so long as she believes in it. *Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 153.
Alleged healing letter (charm) sold: to aid in childbirth.

Actually works. When opened it contains nonsense. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.
Pseudo-magic letter is found to contain insulting remarks.
Pseudo-magic charm (letter): to ward off plague.

Pseudo-magic letter (charm): to aid in engendering
offspring.

A sailor boy sells a seasick Jew “Babylon stones” as a
cure. They are pieces of coal. Type 1532*.
Found to contain snake’s eggs. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Betrayal through pretended fountain of youth.

content: Sale of tree with alleged magic fruit.
child: Sale of tree alleged to produce clothes.
Fishing-rod alleged to take fish to fisherman’s home.
Pseudo-magic acorns: to protect holder‘s pigs.

content: Sale of gilded (plated) ware as gold or silver.

Trickster, as watchman, exchanges worthless bag for bag of
gold at night.
Devil cheated by imposing an impossible task.
child:
Devil is cheated by giving him task: counting the letters
in the church Bible.

He is unable to read
the holy words. England: Baughman.

content:
*Type 1145--1154; Irish: Beal XXI 311, O’Suilleabhain 33;
India: Thompson-Balys.
child:
Man whispers in devil‘s ear that his wife is approaching
with her broom again.

content: Devil pounded in knapsack until he releases man.
Devil’s magic power turned on himself.

The hero who is riding the devil as a horse receives
supernatural strength from plucking a hair from the devil‘s mane. He then spurs
the devil until he agrees to forego his bargain for the man’s soul. Spanish:
Boggs FFC XC 67 No. 508A*.

The man has promised himself to the devil in return for
money. He stuffs his clothes with straw and hangs them up. The devil thinks the
man has hanged himself and is satisfied. Type 1190*.

Devil to release man for performing seemingly impossible
task.
The task is performed by trickery.
child: The evil woman in the glass case as the last commodity.

The man is to belong to the devil as soon as he has sold
his goods. If he has any goods that no one will buy, he is to be free. The man
puts an evil old woman in a glass case. When the devil sees her, he recognizes
her. “Whoever knows her will refuse to buy her.” The man goes free. *Type 1170.
Bringing the devil an unknown animal.

The man sends his naked wife on all fours in tar and
feathers. The devil has never seen such an animal. *Type 1091; *BP I 411, III
358; *Fb “pige” II 816a, “kjende” II 140, “tjære” III
811a; Lithuanian: Balys Legends Nos. 755f.
Guessing name of devil‘s secret plant.

The man’s wife in tar and feathers overhears the devil
tell the secret name of the crop he has discovered (tobacco). The devil says to
the supposed animal, “Get out of my tobacco!” Dh I 194; *BP I 411, III 358.
Not to sleep for three successive nights.

The sleepy man: “I am just thinking, that on earth there
are more crooked trees than straight ones ... more hills than plains ... more
water than land ...” The devil goes to ascertain these things, meanwhile the
man sleeps. Unsuccessful imitation by another man. Lithuanian: Balys Index. No.
813*.

content: Devil gets another soul instead of one bargained for.

The devil bargains with a man for his soul, but the man
fulfills his contract and escapes. In envy two persons commit suicide. The
devil rejoices that though he lost one he has gained two. *Types 361, 362*;
Russian: Andrejev No. 362.
Devil cheated by religious or magic means.
child:
Devil cheated by having priest draw a sacred circle about
the intended victim.

Type 810; Irish: Beal
XXI 309, O‘Suilleabhain 30; Scotland: Baughman.

Devil cheated of his victim by boy having a bible under his
arm.
Devil cheated when his victim becomes a priest.

*Type 811*; Lithuanian: Balys Legends No. 423; Russian:
Andrejev No. 811.

Devil cheated of promised soul by intervention of Virgin
Mary.
The picture of the Virgin Mary saves the priest.
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3268, Legends No. 410ff.
Penance of priest saves him from devil.

The priest, who sold his soul to the devil, orders his
servant to cut him (alive) up into pieces, to crucify him on a tree (and the
like), thus saves his soul from the devils. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3267,
Legends Nos. 405--409.

Devil is unable to take man contracted to him when friends
pray over the corpse.

content: Other ways of cheating the devil of his promised soul.
child:
Devil cheated of his promised soul by making the intended
victim drunk.

The devil may punish the
drunk man’s body but has no power over his soul. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 522.

Devil cheated of his promised soul when the victim sells
his to a comrade.

The latter says, “The
devil can take only one soul from each person. I bought the soul so that when
he comes I can give him one and still save my own.” Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 279.
God cheats the devil of his promised soul.

The devil is to fill a cask full of money. God knocks the
bottom out of the cask. Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 91 No. 773B.

Devil is to get soul of man whether he is buried “inside or
outside of church, above or below ground.”

The man has himself buried in the wall of
the church, partly in and partly out of the ground. (Cf. †H1052.) England:
*Baughman.
Man cheats devil by giving him sole instead of soul.
Devil gets an animal in place of a human being.
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3285, Legends Nos. 472, 489.
Devil gets a flea instead of man‘s soul.

content: Payment to be made at harvest of first crop.

The man plants acorns.
*Type 1185; cf. 1184; Danish: Kristensen Danske Sagn III (1895) 382; German:
Schambach und Müller Niedersächsische Sagen und Märchen No. 170.
Payment to be made when last leaf falls.

The
student is to come into the devil’s power if at the end of a year he does not
at least return for the heaping bushel of gold a level one. The student forthwith
hands back the level bushel and keeps the surplus. *Type 1182; *BP III 14 n. 3,
364.

Horse bought on condition that the buyer pay ten florins and owe sixteen. In
court the buyer insists on the bargain and shows that if he pays the sixteen
florins which he owes he will break the bargain, for then he would no longer
owe. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 110; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

The debt will be returned to the devil when the pigs walk
instead of run home.
Debtor refuses to pay his debt.
child: Refusal to perform part in mutual agreement.
Mutual agreement to sacrifice family members in famine.

Trickster refuses to carry out his part of the bargain.
Louisiana Creole: Fortier MAFLS II 109; India: *Thompson-Balys; Africa: Meinhof
200, (Ekoi): Talbot 337, (Nigeria): Tremaine FL XXI 492, (Vandau): Curtis Songs
and Tales from the Dark Continent (New York, 1920) 44; American Negro
(Georgia): Harris Nights 230ff. Nos. 39, 40, 41; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII
241 No. 14; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 109 n. 2; West Indies:
Flowers 499ff.

Trickster eats other‘s food and then refuses to divide his
own. Christiansen FFC XXIV 46; India: *Thompson-Balys; West Indies: Flowers
501.
The dog refuses to help the wolf.

A farmer plans to kill a faithful old dog. The wolf makes
a plan to save the dog. The latter is to rescue the farmer’s child from the
wolf. The plan succeeds and the dog is rewarded. The wolf in return wants to
steal the farmer‘s sheep. The dog refuses his assistance. *Type 101; Japanese:
Ikeda.
Reward for accomplishment of task deceptively withheld.

Irish myth: Cross; Greek: Fox 81, 94 (Herakles); India:
Thompson-Balys; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G. 13/420).

Dancers given one coin instead of ten and have this taken
away.

Interpreter says they are
complaining that the coin is bad. India: Thompson-Balys.
Refusal to make sacrifice after need is past.

In distress a person promises a sacrifice to a god (saint)
but disregards the promise when the danger passes. Wienert FFC LVI 78f. (ET
438, 448), 139 (ST 442); Halm Aesop Nos. 49, 58; *Crane Vitry 177 No. 102;
Herbert III 8, 36; Scala Celi 56b. No. 316; Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 305; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; India: *Thompson-Balys; West Indies: Flowers 501.
Sailor offers saint a candle as large as a mast.

But he knows that after the storm he will not try to find
such a candle. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 304; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
The sacrifice of the cock is at last carried out.

Postponed until a hawk carries off the cock. Then the
woman says, “O holy St. Martin, I have long owed you a living sacrifice. Take
the cock as sacrifice, and may it be pleasing to you.” Pauli (ed. Bolte) No.
320.
Horse withheld as sacrifice to a saint refuses to move.

The deceiver takes the horse to the church planning to
remove him again, but the horse will not stir until a money equivalent has been
paid. Wesselski Bebel II 157 No. 179.
Sick man offers deity 100 bulls for recovery.

When reminded that he does not own so many bulls he
explains that he doesn’t expect the deity to come to enforce payment. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

Payment of money to the devil impossible, since debtor
learns that the devil is dead.

When the debt is due he offers the creditor his loyalty. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No.
568.
Hogs used as a mortgage collateral.
False offer to return goods in place of payment.
Milk bought on credit poured into one container.

The trickster buys it from various women. After it is all
poured together he says that each may have her own back. *Pauli (ed Bolte) No.
644.
Order to put a small vessel of milk into huge container.

Shrewd group each by himself pours water thinking this
will not be detected if the others pour milk. India: Thompson-Balys.
Trickster gets strong drink by trickery in returning goods.

Trickster returns a bottle of water instead of the bottle
of rum he has just purchased.

Trickster fills his gallon jug half full of water, then has
it filled with rum at the store.

When
seller refuses credit, he pours back half gallon of the liquid--now half rum
and half water. Sometimes trickster repeats operation, getting richer mixture
with each transaction. U.S.: *Baughman.

Debtor tells creditor that he has had his reward in the
hope of payment.
Toad receives water from frog; refuses earth in return.
Servant refused payment because of single mistake.
Man refuses to pay murderer for killing and kills him.
Fish promised in return for bacon.

Later: “Drink up the river, you shall then have fish. All
the fishes there are mine.” Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *1634; Russian:
Andrejev No. *2104.

The
devil keeps calling daily until the gate with the inscription rots. He then
claims his debtor. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1183*; Russian: Andrejev No.
1183*.
Agreement to leave sum of money on coffin of friend.

One puts on his share in cash; other makes out a check for
the total amount and takes cash left by the other. U.S.: *Baughman.
To pay beggar for standing in tank all night.

Beggar sees lights in temple. Payment refused since beggar
has thus warmed himself. India: Thompson-Balys.

Palm rat, when asked to throw down nuts according to
bargain, replies that he is deaf when eating. Africa: Weeks Jungle 400.

content:
Africa (Ekoi): Talbot 68, 375, (Hottentot): Bleek 50 No.
24, (Benga): Nassau 198 No. 29; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 349 No.
61.
child:
By using verse with double meaning man appropriates
borrowed goods.

One day and one night: object borrowed for a day and a
night retained.

Fairy (god?) loses stronghold by consenting to lend it for
“a day and a night.”
Bird has new clothes made: flies away without paying.

Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 37 No. 244; India: *Thompson-Balys;
Japanese: Ikeda.
Drinkers argue about who is to pay.

Trickster sends one of each pair back to be stretched,
leaves town with pair of boots made up of the remaining boots. England:
Baughman.

Man orders a bottle of beer, then returns it and takes a
loaf of bread instead.

He refuses to pay
for the bread because he has returned the beer undrunk. He refuses to pay for
the beer because he has not drunk it. U.S.: Baughman.
Jackal refuses payment for being carried.

Healer to take payment in satisfaction at patient‘s
recovery.
Buyer refuses to pay more. India: Thompson-Balys.

Woman promises marriage for pair of earrings: she escapes
with them.

content:
Trickster summons all creditors at once, precipitates
fight, and escapes payment.
child:
King promises valuable dog to each of two powerful and
mutually hostile tribes.

At feast prepared
by king the two tribes get into fight and king escapes. Irish myth: *Cross.
Fox is promised chickens: is driven off by dogs.

Husband promises a cow to tiger; wife frightens the tiger
away.
Thor is to give his hammer in return for Freyja as wife.

He masks as a woman and kills the giant who is to receive
the hammer. *DeVries Tijdschrift voor Nederlandsche Taal- en Letterkunde XLVII
293ff.; Icelandic: Boberg.

Man cheats devil of reward: to have man if he gets him at
first grasp.

Man holds cat which flies in
devil‘s
face. (Cf. †K210.) French: Sébillot France IV 182.
Conquered warrior kills victor instead of paying.
Forty-nine are moulded out of earth. Greek: Frazer Apollodorus II 179 n. 3.
After payment, snow takes proper form. Irish myth: *Cross.
Saint ransoms prince for much gold and silver.

Later all the money vanishes. Saint replies that since the
money had been created from nothing, it had simply to return to that state.
*Loomis White Magic 127.

Man to be released when earth is placed at his head
(buried). Dies in grave. Irish myth: Cross.

content:
Trickster disguises himself and escapes notice of
creditors.

child: Creditor to wait till debtor is shaved.

The debtor refuses to finish shaving. Wesselski Bebel I
227 No. 132.

Man who owes 1000 ducats has his creditor arrested for
owing him ten.

Thus he hopes to postpone
payment of his own debt. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

content:
Refusal to tell about the Rhine treasure, though condition
demanded is fulfilled when the only one who knows where it is is killed.

The trickster castrates the dupe and is to come the next
day and be castrated himself. He sends his wife as substitute. *Types 153,
1133; Danish: Kristensen Danske Sagn I (1892) 441, (1928) 276--81.
Creditor falsely reported insane when he demands money.

*Wesselski Arlotto II 225 No. 92; Gonnella 98 No. 2;
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1525L*; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

King promises beggars new clothes: burns their old and gets
much gold and silver.

Keeps it. Wesselski
Theorie 15; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Death feigned to avoid paying debts.

Customer takes invitation to buy as invitation to receive
the goods free.

child: Devil loses his grain and gets thistles.

God grants the devil one grain crop, which he can create
by calling its name. The devil is tricked into forgetting the name and calling
“Thistles”. Hence his crop is of thistles. Dh I 185ff.

A man dreams of an egg hanging under his bed. An interpreter demands
half of what he finds as his fee for interpreting the dream. The man finds that
the egg is a silver cup filled with gold crowns. He gives the interpreter part
of the cup but none of the gold. The interpreter says, “He gave me some of the
egg-white but none of the yolk.” *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 616.

Pseudo-magic money-dropping ass beaten to death by buyer;
cheat says: “Return my ass, I shall return your money.”

Payment in worthless goods which are alleged to be valuable
goods transformed.

content: Flattering foreman tricked by his master.

He always answers his master’s remarks, ”I have thought of
the same thing too.“ He falls into the trap when his master says, ”I am going
to sow salt.“ Type 1574*.
